poem:
**Revision**

England's fifteen-year-olds queue for their own autopsy,  
pencils like scalpels, invigilators clocking the pulse.  
A "fair" test: the fairest guillotine.  
Ten per cent less blade, they promise—  
a kinder drop.

Meanwhile, teachers sprint the syllabus,  
students swallow relevance dry.  
Resilience?  
It's a word we pin on a bruise  
and call it learning.

Young people face too many GCSE exams over too short a period. As the Cambridge OCR exam board has shown, England’s 16-year-olds spend longer in exam halls than almost any of their international peers. Last year, the government committed to a 10% reduction in exam time. It’s a step in the right direction, when we need a leap. As the government publishes curriculum reform plans for GCSE subjects this year, we will need more than tinkering around the edges of the curriculum. We need to be laser-focused on what gets added to the curriculum, and bold enough to cut what’s not working.
